Award.AwardTitle: Empowering students to achieve STEM success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is designed to foster a community of scholars and to develop 21st century STEM thinking among a cohort of high-potential, high-need undergraduate students by capitalizing on their common passion for a career in animal biology. Building on strong institutional support in the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, this project identifies and recruits academically-talented yet economically disadvantaged rising sophomores for 16 scholarships of up to $10,000 annually for three years. The intellectual merit of the project comes from advancing the knowledge and the understanding of the multidisciplinary nature of animal biology and agricultural science among highly motivated undergraduate students. These students are developing skill sets based on scientific reasoning, collaboration, and creative problem solving. The plan is to create cohorts of students well-equipped to use STEM skills in the global workplace and in their everyday lives. The project builds on lessons learned from previous NSF S-STEM efforts and leverages institutional commitment and demonstrated departmental excellence.

Broader impacts derive from the new and innovative courses added to the curriculum as a function of this project. Not only will the scholars be allowed to participate, but also other students will as well. Further, publications highlighting the efforts of the undergraduates and the project as a whole are planned. Presentations are planned for the community of agricultural educators, which is an audience that isn't often reached by such projects. By capitalizing on proven pedagogical methods, this program builds the STEM workforce and creates a comprehensive support system to empower economically disadvantaged students and guides them to graduation and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Twenty-one Animal and Dairy Science undergraduate students that were academically gifted but financially burdened were awarded a fellowship through the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) Scholar program at Virginia Tech. Fellowships awarded averaged $30,000.00 per student, significantly alleviating the financial stress the Scholars and their families were under. In addition to monetary assistance, students participated in a series of professional development courses, mentorship activities, and experiential learning opportunities. We were able to gauge the impact of the STEM Scholar program through a series of surveys. Rather than spending time working, STEM Scholars were able to apply to and obtain more internships and jobs that were focused on their career aspirations compared to peers. This is significant as almost all of the fellows were accepted into veterinary school or graduate school. Though the primary focus of this program was to alleviate the financial burden of exceptional students, we were able to better prepare STEM Scholars for their respective careers and identify key areas in our curriculum to improve undergraduate education.

Student learning and peer mentoring was fostered through the development of a learning community that consisted of three professional development courses. We were able to provide training in written and oral communication, leadership, project management, teamwork, self-marketing, diversity and inclusion, intellectual property, negotiating, and critical thinking. Because of the learning community structure, STEM Scholars were able to implement cooperative learning in their own professional development and learn from each other about opportunities and strategies to continue their education. Participants in the STEM Scholar program applied to more internships, received more interviews, and had more job offers compared to other Animal and Dairy Science majors. 

Regardless of program participation, all undergraduate students indicated that more experiential learning and discussion-based courses would improve their learning and the quality of the curriculum. Interestingly, the general student body requested more training in math compared to the STEM Scholars. This may stem from the Scholars being required to take more science-based courses whereas, their peers may have been on academic tracks that did not require as much math. Both experiential learning opportunities and discussion-based courses were incorporated into the STEM Scholar program. One of the courses developed was a topics-based course, which required students to analyze a critical issue using scientific literature. Additionally, STEM Scholars spent two days touring various agricultural agencies in Washington, DC. From this trip one student said, “Professors tell us about the career opportunities we have as agricultural majors, but I have never realized how far those opportunities can stretch until this trip. Getting to meet passionate directors and scientists from different agencies inspired me to keep searching for a STEM career that best fits me.” It is experiential opportunities such as this that can be used to build a pipeline of students for the next generation of scientists.
